question_en: Inferences concerning means?
anbefaling_en: inferences concerning variances: Tow-sample F test to compare variances. (Caution: This test is very sensitive to nonnormality) p 284

question_en: Are the samples independent?
Are all expected values >= 5?
anbefaling_en: Use Fisher s exact test p 371

question_en: Person-time data?
anbefaling_en: Use another underlying distribution or use non-parametric methos pp 341

question_en: Are variances of two samples significantly different? Note: test using F-test
anbefaling_en: Use two-sample t test with equal variances p. 277

question_en: Are variances of two samples significantly different? Note: test using F-test
anbefaling_en: Use two-sample t test with unequal variances p. 288

question_en: Are the samples independent?
Interested in predicting one variable from another?
interested in studying the correlation between two variables?. Both variables normal?
interested in studying the correlation between two variables?. Both variables normal?
Outcome variable normal or can central-limit theorem be assumed to hold?
Other covariates to be controlled for?
Other covariates to be controlled for?
Both variables categorical. Interested in tests of association or reproducibility
Both variables categorical. Interested in tests of association or reproducibility

Other covariates to be controlled for?
Other covariates to be controlled for?

Time of events important?
more than two variables of interest: Outcome variable continous or binary
Survival analysis methods: One-sample problem?
anbefaling_en: Use one-sample test for incidence rates p 727-728

question_en: two-sample problem
anbefaling_en: Use two-sample test for comparison of incidence rates, if no confounding is present. Or methods for statified person-time data, if confounding is present. P 731,734,744

question_en: two-sample problem
anbefaling_en: Interested in test of trend over more than two exposure groups. Use test of trend for incidence rates p 756

question_en: use survival-analysis methods: Interested in comparison of survival curves of two groups with limited control of covariates?
Interested in effects of several risk factors on survival. Willing to assume several curve comes from a weibull distribution?
anbefaling_en: Use Cox proportional hazards model p 774

question_en: Interested in effects of several risk factors on survival. Willing to assume several curve comes from a weibull distribution?
anbefaling_en: use parameter survival methods based on weibull distribution. P 795-801

question_en: 2x2 contingency table?
anbefaling_en: use two-sample test for binomial proportions, or 2x2 contingency table methods if no confounding is present or the mantel-haenszel test if confounding is present. P 354,362,,364

question_en: 2xk contingency table?
anbefaling_en: rRxC contingency table R>2, C>2. Use chi-square test for RxC tables. P 392

question_en: Underlying distribution normal, or can central-limit theorem be assumed to hold?
Categorical data?
anbefaling_en: Use RxC contingency table methods. P 392

question_en: Categorical data?
anbefaling_en: Use another underlying distribution or use nonparametric methods such as kruskal-wallis test. P. 556-557

question_en: Inference concerning \( \mu \)
anbefaling_en: inference concerning sigma: One-sample chi-square test for variances. (caution: this test is very sensitive to nonnormality pp 242-243)

question_en: Interested in trend over k binomial proportions?
anbefaling_en: Use chi-square test for trend, if no confounding is present or the Mantel Extension test if confounding is present. P. 364+623

question_en: Interested in trend over k binomial proportions?
anbefaling_en: Use chi-square test for heterogeneity for 2xk tables p. 392

question_en: Is $\sigma$ known
Is $\sigma$ known
Is the underlying distribution a poisson distribution?
anbefaling_en: Use another underlying distribution or use non-parametric methos pp 330,336

One-sample binomial test: Normal approximation valid?
Ordinal data?
